Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the amount of carbon dioxide produced by termites, stating that they produce 10 times more than humans in a single year, while scientists estimate their carbon emissions to be approximately one-tenth of those created by humans.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that termites actually produce a smaller amount of carbon dioxide compared to humans.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support or evidence to back up the statement that termites produce 10 times more carbon dioxide than humans.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that termites are a significant contributor to carbon dioxide emissions, which is not supported by scientific estimates.
Understate: The claim understates the actual amount of carbon dioxide produced by termites, as they emit approximately one-tenth of the carbon emissions produced by humans in a single year.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation by stating that termites are part of the natural carbon cycle and any emitted CO2 is sequestered again by plants, making termites de facto carbon neutral.
